lines.text: They seek him here,/ They seek him there,/ Those Frenchies seek him everywhere./ Is he in heaven,/ Or is he in hell?/ My own elusive Pimpernel.
Sink me, the lady is a poet.
[they kiss]

[to thug]
It would seem your friend is in distress. To the rescue.
[pushes thug into the river]

[throws a knife into the river]
Yours, I believe.
Sink me, your tailors have betrayed you.
What is it you Frenchies say? Tou-che? You see I'm a poet, and you didn't know it, what?
Robespierre? I'd sooner trust a snake.
Will you not even defend your wife's honor?
Od's fish, m'dear. Would you have me challenge the poor countess to a duel?
He was looking for the Scarlet Pimpernel. I pray he found a fool.
I realized that your noblesse oblige would not permit you to abandon one of your men.
Sink me, if you aren't right. For a change.
My dear chap, I never would have dreamt of depriving you of your moment of triumph. Alas, a moment was all I could spare.
Oh, the English, and their STUPID sense of fair play!
I take it, sir, that you do not approve of our new society.

Approval, sir, in my opinion, demands the attainment of perfection. And in that sense, you rather overrate the charms of your society. I'faith, for one thing, it does seem monstrous ill-dressed for any society, even a new one.
This little revolution of yours is monstrous intolerable.
Percy. Fashionably late, as usual.
Sink me, your highness, it was this damned cravat. Simply refused to tie. I ask you. Sticking out like a pincushion.
I might have known it would be something serious.
The only power that I can see at present, mademoiselle, is the power of your beauty.
Well, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, Sir Percy.
This beholder is enchanted.
If we are to succeed, we must maintain our anonymity, mask our identities. Even if it means suffering the mockery of others. Being taken for fools, fops, nitwits, even cowards.
That's the easy part. The hard part's not being able to boast about our exploits to the ladies.
Let that be a lesson to you, sir. Never take anyone for granted.
They knew that your tears would be the worst possible torture.
They seek him here. They seek him there. Those Frenchies seek him everywhere. Is he in Heaven? Or is he in Hell? That damned, elusive, pimpernel.
An oath to a scoundrel is meaningless.

[accusing Marguerite of denouncing the Marquis de St Cyr]
Can you deny that, Lady Blakeney?
I refuse to confirm or deny such accusations. For this is no trial - and you are no judge.
True, Madame. God will be your judge.
God bless the Scarlet Pimpernel, whoever he may be. Surely he must be an angel in disguise.
Amen.
We shall execute our king instead, sir, and exalt our tailors.
More's the pity. Then your tailors will rule the land, and no one will make the clothes. So much for French fashion, and French politics.
I don't know whether you're mad, or...
Desperately in love? 'Tis all the same. Tell me, if you can, that you do not feel it, too.
If I were to tell you that I adore you, would you have me do so stintingly?
*Adore* me?
Or would you have me declare it as I feel it, with all my heart?
You must tell me all about yourself, in every detail, but oh, so slowly, so very slowly, so that it takes a very, very long time.
You used me.
Yes. And as long as you are here to serve the committee, I shall continue to use you.
I am pleased to see that you have come to your senses.
You left me little choice.
That was the general idea.
I see now what begins as a dream can end as a nightmare. Some causes can become warped and twisted, like some men.
What has poor Armand done to be condemned to matrimony?
Her heart's as soft as her head.

[on his poem]
Well, the pretty thing rhymes in four places, don't you see? And if a rhyme rhymes, it makes a poem, if you follow me.
As if it were crystal clear... my dear!
Ceased? I will love her to the day I die. That is the tragedy.
